summary: The Sri Lanka national cricket team, nicknamed The Lions, represents Sri Lanka in international cricket. It is a full member of the International Cricket Council (ICC) with Test, One-Day International (ODI) and T20 International (T20I) status.

value.label: Sri Lanka
Sri Lanka Cricket
Dimuth Karunaratne
Dimuth Karunaratne
Lasith Malinga

value.label: Chandika Hathurusingha

Galle International Stadium is a cricket stadium in Galle, Sri Lanka, situated near the Galle fort and fringed on two sides by the Indian Ocean. It is considered to be one of the most picturesque cricket grounds in the world.

image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license.

value.label: Renamed Sri Lanka in 1972, the national team first competed in top level international cricket in 1975, when they played against West Indies during 1975 Cricket World Cup
After Sri Lanka was awarded Test status in 21 July 1981 as eighth Test playing nation, they had to wait until 6 September 1985, where Sri Lanka recorded their first Test win by beating India
Sri Lanka had to wait for more than 7 years for their next series victory, which came against New Zealand in December 1992.
Sri Lanka have registered more wins against Pakistan and Bangladesh than any other team, with 14.
Separamadu Lasith Malinga bowls right-arm fast-medium and, is commonly used as a specialist death bowler, which lead to his nicknames, "Slinga Malinga" and "Malinga the Slinga".

image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0 Generic license.

value.label: Chandimal holds the joint record for taking the most number of catches in a single T20I as a fielder.

value.label: Angelo Davis Mathews, is a professional Sri Lankan cricketer and a former captain in all formats.

value.label: Thisara Perera, is a professional Sri Lankan cricketer. He was purchased by the Chennai Super Kings for US$50,000 in the auction for the 2010 Indian Premier League.

value.label: Winners of the 1996 Cricket World Cup, which they co-hosted with India & Pakistan

facts.label: Winners of the 2002 ICC Champions Trophy

value.label: Joint winners of the 2002 ICC Champions Trophy, which they also hosted in their own right

The ICC Champions Trophy was a one day international (ODI) cricket tournament organised by the International Cricket Council (ICC), second in importance only to the Cricket World Cup. Its name was changed to the Champions Trophy in 2002.

image.altText: Image of Winners of the 2002 ICC Champions Trophy

value.label: Runners up in the 2007 Cricket World Cup, hosted by the West Indies

The 2007 Cricket World Cup (officially known as ICC Cricket World Cup 2007) was the 9th edition of the Cricket World Cup tournament that took place in the West Indies from 13 March to 28 April 2007, using the sport's One Day International (ODI) format.
Runners up of the 2011 Cricket World Cup, which they co-hosted with India & Bangladesh.
Dilmah
